member.name: T:Native.DibCompression
member.summary: DIB.

member.name: F:Native.DibCompression.RGB
member.summary: An uncompressed format.

member.name: F:Native.DibCompression.RLE8
member.summary: A run-length encoded (RLE) format for bitmaps with 8 bpp. The compression format is a 2-byte format consisting of a count byte followed by a byte containing a color index.

member.name: F:Native.DibCompression.RLE4
member.summary: An RLE format for bitmaps with 4 bpp. The compression format is a 2-byte format consisting of a count byte followed by two word-length color indexes.

member.name: F:Native.DibCompression.BITFIELDS
member.summary: Specifies that the bitmap is not compressed and that the color table consists of three DWORD color masks that specify the red, green, and blue components, respectively, of each pixel. This is valid when used with 16- and 32-bpp bitmaps.

member.name: F:Native.DibCompression.JPEG
member.summary: Indicates that the image is a JPEG image.

member.name: F:Native.DibCompression.PNG
member.summary: Indicates that the image is a PNG image.

member.name: F:Native.DibUsage.DIB_RGB_COLORS
member.summary: Color table in RGBs.

member.name: F:Native.DibUsage.DIB_PAL_COLORS
member.summary: Color table in palette indices.

member.name: F:Native.StretchBltMode.INVALID
member.summary: Invalid value.

member.name: F:Native.StretchBltMode.INVALID_PARAMETER
member.summary: One or more of the input parameters is invalid.

member.name: F:Native.StretchBltMode.BLACKONWHITE
member.summary: Performs a Boolean AND operation using the color values for the eliminated and existing pixels. If the bitmap is a monochrome bitmap, this mode preserves black pixels at the expense of white pixels.

member.name: F:Native.StretchBltMode.WHITEONBLACK
member.summary: Performs a Boolean OR operation using the color values for the eliminated and existing pixels. If the bitmap is a monochrome bitmap, this mode preserves white pixels at the expense of black pixels.

member.name: F:Native.StretchBltMode.COLORONCOLOR
member.summary: Deletes the pixels. This mode deletes all eliminated lines of pixels without trying to preserve their information.

member.name: F:Native.StretchBltMode.HALFTONE
member.summary: Maps pixels from the source rectangle into blocks of pixels in the destination rectangle. The average color over the destination block of pixels approximates the color of the source pixels. After setting the HALFTONE stretching mode, an application must call the SetBrushOrgEx function to set the brush origin. If it fails to do so, brush misalignment occurs.

member.name: T:Native.ScrollWindowFlags
member.summary: ScrollWindowEx.

member.name: F:Native.ScrollWindowFlags.SCROLLCHILDREN
member.summary: Scroll children within *lprcScroll.

member.name: F:Native.ScrollWindowFlags.INVALIDATE
member.summary: Invalidate after scrolling.

member.name: F:Native.ScrollWindowFlags.ERASE
member.summary: If SW_INVALIDATE, don't send .

member.name: F:Native.ScrollWindowFlags.SMOOTHSCROLL
member.summary: Use smooth scrolling.

member.name: F:Native.SW.FORCEMINIMIZE
member.summary: Minimizes a window, even if the thread that owns the window is not responding. This flag should only be used when minimizing windows from a different thread.

member.name: F:Native.SW.HIDE
member.summary: Hides the window and activates another window.

member.name: F:Native.SW.MAXIMIZE
member.summary: Maximizes the specified window.

member.name: F:Native.SW.MINIMIZE
member.summary: Minimizes the specified window and activates the next top-level window in the Z order.

member.name: F:Native.SW.RESTORE
member.summary: Activates and displays the window. If the window is minimized or maximized, the system restores it to its original size and position. An application should specify this flag when restoring a minimized window.

member.name: F:Native.SW.SHOW
member.summary: Activates the window and displays it in its current size and position.

member.name: F:Native.SW.SHOWDEFAULT
member.summary: Sets the show state based on the SW_ value specified in the STARTUPINFO structure passed to the CreateProcess function by the program that started the application.

member.name: F:Native.SW.SHOWMAXIMIZED
member.summary: Activates the window and displays it as a maximized window.

member.name: F:Native.SW.SHOWMINIMIZED
member.summary: Activates the window and displays it as a minimized window.

member.name: F:Native.SW.SHOWMINNOACTIVE
member.summary: Displays the window as a minimized window. This value is similar to , except the window is not activated.

member.name: F:Native.SW.SHOWNA
member.summary: Displays the window in its current size and position. This value is similar to , except that the window is not activated.

member.name: F:Native.SW.SHOWNOACTIVATE
member.summary: Displays a window in its most recent size and position. This value is similar to , except that the window is not activated.

member.name: F:Native.SW.SHOWNORMAL
member.summary: Activates and displays a window. If the window is minimized or maximized, the system restores it to its original size and position. An application should specify this flag when displaying the window for the first time.

member.name: T:Native.WM
member.summary: Windows message.

member.name: T:Native.CS
member.summary: Window class styles.

member.name: F:Native.CS.BYTEALIGNCLIENT
member.summary: Aligns the window's client area on a byte boundary (in the x direction). This style affects the width of the window and its horizontal placement on the display.

member.name: F:Native.CS.BYTEALIGNWINDOW
member.summary: Aligns the window on a byte boundary (in the x direction). This style affects the width of the window and its horizontal placement on the display.

member.name: F:Native.CS.CLASSDC
member.summary: Allocates one device context to be shared by all windows in the class. Because window classes are process specific, it is possible for multiple threads of an application to create a window of the same class. It is also possible for the threads to attempt to use the device context simultaneously. When this happens, the system allows only one thread to successfully finish its drawing operation.

member.name: F:Native.CS.DBLCLKS
member.summary: Sends a double-click message to the window procedure when the user double-clicks the mouse while the cursor is within a window belonging to the class.

member.name: F:Native.CS.DROPSHADOW
member.summary: Enables the drop shadow effect on a window. The effect is turned on and off through SPI_SETDROPSHADOW. Typically, this is enabled for small, short-lived windows such as menus to emphasize their Z order relationship to other windows.

member.name: F:Native.CS.GLOBALCLASS
member.summary: Indicates that the window class is an application global class. For more information, see the "Application Global Classes" section of About Window Classes.

member.name: F:Native.CS.HREDRAW
member.summary: Redraws the entire window if a movement or size adjustment changes the width of the client area.

member.name: F:Native.CS.NOCLOSE
member.summary: Disables Close on the window menu.

member.name: F:Native.CS.OWNDC
member.summary: Allocates a unique device context for each window in the class.

member.name: F:Native.CS.PARENTDC
member.summary: Sets the clipping rectangle of the child window to that of the parent window so that the child can draw on the parent. A window with the style bit receives a regular device context from the system's cache of device contexts. It does not give the child the parent's device context or device context settings. Specifying enhances an application's performance.

member.name: F:Native.CS.SAVEBITS
member.summary: Saves, as a bitmap, the portion of the screen image obscured by a window of this class. When the window is removed, the system uses the saved bitmap to restore the screen image, including other windows that were obscured. Therefore, the system does not send messages to windows that were obscured if the memory used by the bitmap has not been discarded and if other screen actions have not invalidated the stored image.

member.name: F:Native.CS.VREDRAW
member.summary: Redraws the entire window if a movement or size adjustment changes the height of the client area.

member.name: T:Native.WS
member.summary: Window styles.

member.name: F:Native.WS.BORDER
member.summary: The window has a thin-line border.

member.name: F:Native.WS.CAPTION
member.summary: The window has a title bar (includes the style).

member.name: F:Native.WS.CHILD
member.summary: The window is a child window. A window with this style cannot have a menu bar. This style cannot be used with the style.

member.name: F:Native.WS.CHILDWINDOW
member.summary: Same as style.

member.name: F:Native.WS.CLIPCHILDREN
member.summary: Excludes the area occupied by child windows when drawing occurs within the parent window. This style is used when creating the parent window.

member.name: F:Native.WS.CLIPSIBLINGS
member.summary: Clips child windows relative to each other; that is, when a particular child window receives a message, the style clips all other overlapping child windows out of the region of the child window to be updated. If is not specified and child windows overlap, it is possible, when drawing within the client area of a child window, to draw within the client area of a neighboring child window.

member.name: F:Native.WS.DISABLED
member.summary: The window is initially disabled. A disabled window cannot receive input from the user. To change this after a window has been created, use the EnableWindow function.

member.name: F:Native.WS.DLGFRAME
member.summary: The window has a border of a style typically used with dialog boxes. A window with this style cannot have a title bar.

member.name: F:Native.WS.GROUP
member.summary: The window is the first control of a group of controls. The group consists of this first control and all controls defined after it, up to the next control with the style. The first control in each group usually has the style so that the user can move from group to group. The user can subsequently change the keyboard focus from one control in the group to the next control in the group by using the direction keys.

member.name: F:Native.WS.HSCROLL
member.summary: The window has a horizontal scroll bar.

member.name: F:Native.WS.ICONIC
member.summary: The window is initially minimized. Same as the style.

member.name: F:Native.WS.MAXIMIZE
member.summary: The window is initially maximized.

member.name: F:Native.WS.MAXIMIZEBOX
member.summary: The window has a maximize button. Cannot be combined with the style. The style must also be specified.

member.name: F:Native.WS.MINIMIZE
member.summary: The window is initially minimized. Same as the style.

member.name: F:Native.WS.MINIMIZEBOX
member.summary: The window has a minimize button. Cannot be combined with the style. The style must also be specified.

member.name: F:Native.WS.OVERLAPPED
member.summary: The window is an overlapped window. An overlapped window has a title bar and a border. Same as the style.

member.name: F:Native.WS.OVERLAPPEDWINDOW
member.summary: The window is an overlapped window. Same as the style.

member.name: F:Native.WS.POPUP
member.summary: The windows is a pop-up window. This style cannot be used with the style.

member.name: F:Native.WS.POPUPWINDOW
member.summary: The window is a pop-up window. The and styles must be combined to make the window menu visible.

member.name: F:Native.WS.SIZEBOX
member.summary: The window has a sizing border. Same as the style.

member.name: F:Native.WS.SYSMENU
member.summary: The window has a window menu on its title bar. The style must also be specified.

member.name: F:Native.WS.TABSTOP
member.summary: The window is a control that can receive the keyboard focus when the user presses the TAB key. Pressing the TAB key changes the keyboard focus to the next control with the style.

member.name: F:Native.WS.THICKFRAME
member.summary: The window has a sizing border. Same as the style.

member.name: F:Native.WS.TILED
member.summary: The window is an overlapped window. An overlapped window has a title bar and a border. Same as the style.

member.name: F:Native.WS.TILEDWINDOW
member.summary: The window is an overlapped window. Same as the style.

member.name: F:Native.WS.VISIBLE
member.summary: The window is initially visible. This style can be turned on and off by using the ShowWindow or SetWindowPos function.

member.name: F:Native.WS.VSCROLL
member.summary: The window has a vertical scroll bar.

member.name: T:Native.WS_EX
member.summary: Extended window styles.

member.name: F:Native.WS_EX.ACCEPTFILES
member.summary: The window accepts drag-drop files.

member.name: F:Native.WS_EX.APPWINDOW
member.summary: Forces a top-level window onto the taskbar when the window is visible.

member.name: F:Native.WS_EX.CLIENTEDGE
member.summary: The window has a border with a sunken edge.

member.name: F:Native.WS_EX.COMPOSITED
member.summary: Paints all descendants of a window in bottom-to-top painting order using double-buffering. This cannot be used if the window has a class style of either CS_OWNDC or CS_CLASSDC.
member.remarks: Windows 2000: This style is not supported.

member.name: F:Native.WS_EX.CONTEXTHELP
member.summary: The title bar of the window includes a question mark. When the user clicks the question mark, the cursor changes to a question mark with a pointer. If the user then clicks a child window, the child receives a message. The child window should pass the message to the parent window procedure, which should call the WinHelp function using the HELP_WM_HELP command. The Help application displays a pop-up window that typically contains help for the child window. cannot be used with the or styles.

member.name: F:Native.WS_EX.CONTROLPARENT
member.summary: The window itself contains child windows that should take part in dialog box navigation. If this style is specified, the dialog manager recurses into children of this window when performing navigation operations such as handling the TAB key, an arrow key, or a keyboard mnemonic.

member.name: F:Native.WS_EX.DLGMODALFRAME
member.summary: The window has a double border; the window can, optionally, be created with a title bar by specifying the style in the dwStyle parameter.

member.name: F:Native.WS_EX.LAYERED
member.summary: The window is a layered window. This style cannot be used if the window has a class style of either or .

member.name: F:Native.WS_EX.LAYOUTRTL
member.summary: If the shell language is Hebrew, Arabic, or another language that supports reading order alignment, the horizontal origin of the window is on the right edge. Increasing horizontal values advance to the left.

member.name: F:Native.WS_EX.LEFT
member.summary: The window has generic left-aligned properties. This is the default.

member.name: F:Native.WS_EX.LEFTSCROLLBAR
member.summary: If the shell language is Hebrew, Arabic, or another language that supports reading order alignment, the vertical scroll bar (if present) is to the left of the client area. For other languages, the style is ignored.

member.name: F:Native.WS_EX.LTRREADING
member.summary: The window text is displayed using left-to-right reading-order properties. This is the default.

member.name: F:Native.WS_EX.MDICHILD
member.summary: The window is a MDI child window.

member.name: F:Native.WS_EX.NOACTIVATE
member.summary: A top-level window created with this style does not become the foreground window when the user clicks it. The system does not bring this window to the foreground when the user minimizes or closes the foreground window.

member.name: F:Native.WS_EX.NOINHERITLAYOUT
member.summary: The window does not pass its window layout to its child windows.

member.name: F:Native.WS_EX.NOPARENTNOTIFY
member.summary: The child window created with this style does not send the message to its parent window when it is created or destroyed.

member.name: F:Native.WS_EX.NOREDIRECTIONBITMAP
member.summary: The window does not render to a redirection surface. This is for windows that do not have visible content or that use mechanisms other than surfaces to provide their visual.

member.name: F:Native.WS_EX.OVERLAPPEDWINDOW
member.summary: The window is an overlapped window.

member.name: F:Native.WS_EX.PALETTEWINDOW
member.summary: The window is palette window, which is a modeless dialog box that presents an array of commands.

member.name: F:Native.WS_EX.RIGHT
member.summary: The window has generic "right-aligned" properties. This depends on the window class. This style has an effect only if the shell language is Hebrew, Arabic, or another language that supports reading-order alignment; otherwise, the style is ignored.

member.name: F:Native.WS_EX.RIGHTSCROLLBAR
member.summary: The vertical scroll bar (if present) is to the right of the client area. This is the default.

member.name: F:Native.WS_EX.RTLREADING
member.summary: If the shell language is Hebrew, Arabic, or another language that supports reading-order alignment, the window text is displayed using right-to-left reading-order properties. For other languages, the style is ignored.

member.name: F:Native.WS_EX.STATICEDGE
member.summary: The window has a three-dimensional border style intended to be used for items that do not accept user input.

member.name: F:Native.WS_EX.TOOLWINDOW
member.summary: The window is intended to be used as a floating toolbar. A tool window has a title bar that is shorter than a normal title bar, and the window title is drawn using a smaller font. A tool window does not appear in the taskbar or in the dialog that appears when the user presses ALT+TAB. If a tool window has a system menu, its icon is not displayed on the title bar. However, you can display the system menu by right-clicking or by typing ALT+SPACE.

member.name: F:Native.WS_EX.TOPMOST
member.summary: The window should be placed above all non-topmost windows and should stay above them, even when the window is deactivated. To add or remove this style, use the SetWindowPos function.

member.name: F:Native.WS_EX.TRANSPARENT
member.summary: The window should not be painted until siblings beneath the window (that were created by the same thread) have been painted. The window appears transparent because the bits of underlying sibling windows have already been painted. To achieve transparency without these restrictions, use the SetWindowRgn function.

member.name: F:Native.WS_EX.WINDOWEDGE
member.summary: The window has a border with a raised edge.

member.name: F:Native.CWP.ALL
member.summary: Does not skip any child windows.

member.name: F:Native.CWP.SKIPDISABLED
member.summary: Skips disabled child windows.

member.name: F:Native.CWP.SKIPINVISIBLE
member.summary: Skips invisible child windows.

member.name: F:Native.CWP.SKIPTRANSPARENT
member.summary: Skips transparent child windows.

member.name: T:Native.SM
member.summary: System metric.

member.name: F:Native.SM.ARRANGE
member.summary: The flags that specify how the system arranged minimized windows.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CLEANBOOT
member.summary: The value that specifies how the system is started: 0 = Normal boot 1 = Fail-safe boot 2 = Fail-safe with network boot A fail-safe boot (also called SafeBoot, Safe Mode, or Clean Boot) bypasses the user startup files.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CMONITORS
member.summary: The number of display monitors on a desktop.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CMOUSEBUTTONS
member.summary: The number of buttons on a mouse, or zero if no mouse is installed.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXBORDER
member.summary: The width of a window border, in pixels. This is equivalent to the value for windows with the 3-D look.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXCURSOR
member.summary: The width of a cursor, in pixels. The system cannot create cursors of other sizes.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXDLGFRAME
member.summary: This value is the same as .

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXDOUBLECLK
member.summary: The width of the rectangle around the location of a first click in a double-click sequence, in pixels. The second click must occur within the rectangle that is defined by and for the system to consider the two clicks a double-click. The two clicks must also occur within a specified time.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXPADDEDBORDER
member.summary: The amount of border padding for captioned windows, in pixels. Windows XP/2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXDRAG
member.summary: The number of pixels on either side of a mouse-down point that the mouse pointer can move before a drag operation begins. This allows the user to click and release the mouse button easily without unintentionally starting a drag operation. If this value is negative, it is subtracted from the left of the mouse-down point and added to the right of it.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXEDGE
member.summary: The width of a 3-D border, in pixels. This metric is the 3-D counterpart of .

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXFIXEDFRAME
member.summary: The thickness of the frame around the perimeter of a window that has a caption but is not sizable, in pixels. is the height of the horizontal border, and is the width of the vertical border. This value is the same as SM_CXDLGFRAME.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXFOCUSBORDER
member.summary: The width of the left and right edges of the focus rectangle that the DrawFocusRect draws. This value is in pixels.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXFRAME
member.summary: This value is the same as .

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXFULLSCREEN
member.summary: The width of the client area for a full-screen window on the primary display monitor, in pixels. To get the coordinates of the portion of the screen that is not obscured by the system taskbar or by application desktop toolbars, call the SystemParametersInfo function with the SPI_GETWORKAREA value.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXHSCROLL
member.summary: The width of the arrow bitmap on a horizontal scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXHTHUMB
member.summary: The width of the thumb box in a horizontal scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXICON
member.summary: The default width of an icon, in pixels. The LoadIcon function can load only icons with the dimensions that and specifies.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXICONSPACING
member.summary: The width of a grid cell for items in large icon view, in pixels. Each item fits into a rectangle of size by when arranged. This value is always greater than or equal to .

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXMAXIMIZED
member.summary: The default width, in pixels, of a maximized top-level window on the primary display monitor.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXMAXTRACK
member.summary: The default maximum width of a window that has a caption and sizing borders, in pixels. This metric refers to the entire desktop. The user cannot drag the window frame to a size larger than these dimensions. A window can override this value by processing the message.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXMENUCHECK
member.summary: The width of the default menu check-mark bitmap, in pixels.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXMENUSIZE
member.summary: The width of menu bar buttons, such as the child window close button that is used in the multiple document interface, in pixels.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXMIN
member.summary: The minimum width of a window, in pixels.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXMINIMIZED
member.summary: The width of a minimized window, in pixels.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXMINSPACING
member.summary: The width of a grid cell for a minimized window, in pixels. Each minimized window fits into a rectangle this size when arranged. This value is always greater than or equal to .

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXMINTRACK
member.summary: The minimum tracking width of a window, in pixels. The user cannot drag the window frame to a size smaller than these dimensions. A window can override this value by processing the message.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXSCREEN
member.summary: The width of the screen of the primary display monitor, in pixels. This is the same value obtained by calling GetDeviceCaps as follows: GetDeviceCaps( hdcPrimaryMonitor, HORZRES).

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXSIZE
member.summary: The width of a button in a window caption or title bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXSIZEFRAME
member.summary: The thickness of the sizing border around the perimeter of a window that can be resized, in pixels. is the width of the horizontal border, and is the height of the vertical border. This value is the same as SM_CXFRAME.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXSMICON
member.summary: The recommended width of a small icon, in pixels. Small icons typically appear in window captions and in small icon view.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXSMSIZE
member.summary: The width of small caption buttons, in pixels.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXVIRTUALSCREEN
member.summary: The width of the virtual screen, in pixels. The virtual screen is the bounding rectangle of all display monitors. The metric is the coordinates for the left side of the virtual screen.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CXVSCROLL
member.summary: The width of a vertical scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYBORDER
member.summary: The height of a window border, in pixels. This is equivalent to the value for windows with the 3-D look.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYCAPTION
member.summary: The height of a caption area, in pixels.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYCURSOR
member.summary: The height of a cursor, in pixels. The system cannot create cursors of other sizes.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYDLGFRAME
member.summary: This value is the same as .

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYDOUBLECLK
member.summary: The height of the rectangle around the location of a first click in a double-click sequence, in pixels. The second click must occur within the rectangle defined by and for the system to consider the two clicks a double-click. The two clicks must also occur within a specified time.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYDRAG
member.summary: The number of pixels above and below a mouse-down point that the mouse pointer can move before a drag operation begins. This allows the user to click and release the mouse button easily without unintentionally starting a drag operation. If this value is negative, it is subtracted from above the mouse-down point and added below it.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYEDGE
member.summary: The height of a 3-D border, in pixels. This is the 3-D counterpart of .

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYFIXEDFRAME
member.summary: The thickness of the frame around the perimeter of a window that has a caption but is not sizable, in pixels. is the height of the horizontal border, and is the width of the vertical border. This value is the same as .

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYFOCUSBORDER
member.summary: The height of the top and bottom edges of the focus rectangle drawn by DrawFocusRect. This value is in pixels.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYFRAME
member.summary: This value is the same as .

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYFULLSCREEN
member.summary: The height of the client area for a full-screen window on the primary display monitor, in pixels. To get the coordinates of the portion of the screen not obscured by the system taskbar or by application desktop toolbars, call the SystemParametersInfo function with the SPI_GETWORKAREA value.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYHSCROLL
member.summary: The height of a horizontal scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYICON
member.summary: The default height of an icon, in pixels. The LoadIcon function can load only icons with the dimensions and .

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYICONSPACING
member.summary: The height of a grid cell for items in large icon view, in pixels. Each item fits into a rectangle of size by when arranged. This value is always greater than or equal to .

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYKANJIWINDOW
member.summary: For double byte character set versions of the system, this is the height of the Kanji window at the bottom of the screen, in pixels.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYMAXIMIZED
member.summary: The default height, in pixels, of a maximized top-level window on the primary display monitor.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYMAXTRACK
member.summary: The default maximum height of a window that has a caption and sizing borders, in pixels. This metric refers to the entire desktop. The user cannot drag the window frame to a size larger than these dimensions. A window can override this value by processing the message.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYMENU
member.summary: The height of a single-line menu bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYMENUCHECK
member.summary: The height of the default menu check-mark bitmap, in pixels.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYMENUSIZE
member.summary: The height of menu bar buttons, such as the child window close button that is used in the multiple document interface, in pixels.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYMIN
member.summary: The minimum height of a window, in pixels.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYMINIMIZED
member.summary: The height of a minimized window, in pixels.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYMINSPACING
member.summary: The height of a grid cell for a minimized window, in pixels. Each minimized window fits into a rectangle this size when arranged. This value is always greater than or equal to .

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYMINTRACK
member.summary: The minimum tracking height of a window, in pixels. The user cannot drag the window frame to a size smaller than these dimensions. A window can override this value by processing the message.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYSCREEN
member.summary: The height of the screen of the primary display monitor, in pixels. This is the same value obtained by calling GetDeviceCaps as follows: GetDeviceCaps( hdcPrimaryMonitor, VERTRES).

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYSIZE
member.summary: The height of a button in a window caption or title bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYSIZEFRAME
member.summary: The thickness of the sizing border around the perimeter of a window that can be resized, in pixels. is the width of the horizontal border, and is the height of the vertical border. This value is the same as .

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYSMCAPTION
member.summary: The height of a small caption, in pixels.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYSMICON
member.summary: The recommended height of a small icon, in pixels. Small icons typically appear in window captions and in small icon view.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYSMSIZE
member.summary: The height of small caption buttons, in pixels.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYVIRTUALSCREEN
member.summary: The height of the virtual screen, in pixels. The virtual screen is the bounding rectangle of all display monitors. The metric is the coordinates for the top of the virtual screen.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYVSCROLL
member.summary: The height of the arrow bitmap on a vertical scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Native.SM.CYVTHUMB
member.summary: The height of the thumb box in a vertical scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Native.SM.DBCSENABLED
member.summary: Nonzero if User32.dll supports DBCS; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:Native.SM.DEBUG
member.summary: Nonzero if the debug version of User.exe is installed; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:Native.SM.DIGITIZER
member.summary: Nonzero if the current operating system is Windows 7 or Windows Server 2008 R2 and the Tablet PC Input service is started; otherwise, 0. The return value is a bitmask that specifies the type of digitizer input supported by the device.

member.name: F:Native.SM.IMMENABLED
member.summary: Nonzero if Input Method Manager/Input Method Editor features are enabled; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:Native.SM.MAXIMUMTOUCHES
member.summary: Nonzero if there are digitizers in the system; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:Native.SM.MEDIACENTER
member.summary: Nonzero if the current operating system is the Windows XP, Media Center Edition, 0 if not.

member.name: F:Native.SM.MENUDROPALIGNMENT
member.summary: Nonzero if drop-down menus are right-aligned with the corresponding menu-bar item; 0 if the menus are left-aligned.

member.name: F:Native.SM.MIDEASTENABLED
member.summary: Nonzero if the system is enabled for Hebrew and Arabic languages, 0 if not.

member.name: F:Native.SM.MOUSEPRESENT
member.summary: Nonzero if a mouse is installed; otherwise, 0. This value is rarely zero, because of support for virtual mice and because some systems detect the presence of the port instead of the presence of a mouse.

member.name: F:Native.SM.MOUSEHORIZONTALWHEELPRESENT
member.summary: Nonzero if a mouse with a horizontal scroll wheel is installed; otherwise 0.

member.name: F:Native.SM.MOUSEWHEELPRESENT
member.summary: Nonzero if a mouse with a vertical scroll wheel is installed; otherwise 0.

member.name: F:Native.SM.NETWORK
member.summary: The least significant bit is set if a network is present; otherwise, it is cleared. The other bits are reserved for future use.

member.name: F:Native.SM.PENWINDOWS
member.summary: Nonzero if the Microsoft Windows for Pen computing extensions are installed; zero otherwise.

member.name: F:Native.SM.REMOTECONTROL
member.summary: This system metric is used in a Terminal Services environment to determine if the current Terminal Server session is being remotely controlled. Its value is nonzero if the current session is remotely controlled; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:Native.SM.REMOTESESSION
member.summary: This system metric is used in a Terminal Services environment. If the calling process is associated with a Terminal Services client session, the return value is nonzero. If the calling process is associated with the Terminal Services console session, the return value is 0.

member.name: F:Native.SM.SAMEDISPLAYFORMAT
member.summary: Nonzero if all the display monitors have the same color format, otherwise, 0. Two displays can have the same bit depth, but different color formats. For example, the red, green, and blue pixels can be encoded with different numbers of bits, or those bits can be located in different places in a pixel color value.

member.name: F:Native.SM.SECURE
member.summary: This system metric should be ignored; it always returns 0.

member.name: F:Native.SM.SERVERR2
member.summary: The build number if the system is Windows Server 2003 R2; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:Native.SM.SHOWSOUNDS
member.summary: Nonzero if the user requires an application to present information visually in situations where it would otherwise present the information only in audible form; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:Native.SM.SHUTTINGDOWN
member.summary: Nonzero if the current session is shutting down; otherwise, 0.
member.remarks: Windows 2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:Native.SM.SLOWMACHINE
member.summary: Nonzero if the computer has a low-end (slow) processor; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:Native.SM.SWAPBUTTON
member.summary: Nonzero if the meanings of the left and right mouse buttons are swapped; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:Native.SM.STARTER
member.summary: Nonzero if the current operating system is Windows 7 Starter Edition, Windows Vista Starter, or Windows XP Starter Edition; otherwise, 0.

member.name: F:Native.SM.TABLETPC
member.summary: Nonzero if the current operating system is the Windows XP Tablet PC edition or if the current operating system is Windows Vista or Windows 7 and the Tablet PC Input service is started; otherwise, 0. The setting indicates the type of digitizer input supported by a device running Windows 7 or Windows Server 2008 R2.

member.name: F:Native.SM.XVIRTUALSCREEN
member.summary: The coordinates for the left side of the virtual screen. The virtual screen is the bounding rectangle of all display monitors. The metric is the width of the virtual screen.

member.name: F:Native.SM.YVIRTUALSCREEN
member.summary: The coordinates for the top of the virtual screen. The virtual screen is the bounding rectangle of all display monitors. The metric is the height of the virtual screen.

member.name: T:Native.SWP
member.summary: Flags for .

member.name: F:Native.SWP.NOSIZE
member.summary: Retains the current size (ignores the cx and cy parameters).

member.name: F:Native.SWP.NOMOVE
member.summary: Retains the current position (ignores x and y parameters).

member.name: F:Native.SWP.NOZORDER
member.summary: Retains the current Z order (ignores the hWndInsertAfter parameter).

member.name: F:Native.SWP.NOREDRAW
member.summary: Does not redraw changes. If this flag is set, no repainting of any kind occurs. This applies to the client area, the nonclient area (including the title bar and scroll bars), and any part of the parent window uncovered as a result of the window being moved. When this flag is set, the application must explicitly invalidate or redraw any parts of the window and parent window that need redrawing.

member.name: F:Native.SWP.NOACTIVATE
member.summary: Does not activate the window. If this flag is not set, the window is activated and moved to the top of either the topmost or non-topmost group (depending on the setting of the hWndInsertAfter parameter).

member.name: F:Native.SWP.DRAWFRAME
member.summary: Draws a frame (defined in the window's class description) around the window.

member.name: F:Native.SWP.FRAMECHANGED
member.summary: Applies new frame styles set using the function. Sends a message to the window, even if the window's size is not being changed. If this flag is not specified, is sent only when the window's size is being changed.

member.name: F:Native.SWP.SHOWWINDOW
member.summary: Displays the window.

member.name: F:Native.SWP.HIDEWINDOW
member.summary: Hides the window.

member.name: F:Native.SWP.NOCOPYBITS
member.summary: Discards the entire contents of the client area. If this flag is not specified, the valid contents of the client area are saved and copied back into the client area after the window is sized or repositioned.

member.name: F:Native.SWP.NOOWNERZORDER
member.summary: Does not change the owner window's position in the Z order.

member.name: F:Native.SWP.NOREPOSITION
member.summary: Same as the flag.

member.name: F:Native.SWP.NOSENDCHANGING
member.summary: Prevents the window from receiving the message.

member.name: F:Native.SWP.DEFERERASE
member.summary: Prevents generation of the message.

member.name: F:Native.SWP.ASYNCWINDOWPOS
member.summary: If the calling thread and the thread that owns the window are attached to different input queues, the system posts the request to the thread that owns the window. This prevents the calling thread from blocking its execution while other threads process the request.

member.name: F:Native.DWMWA.FREEZE_REPRESENTATION
member.summary: [set] Force this window to freeze the thumbnail without live update.

member.summary: Flash both the window caption and taskbar button. This is equivalent to setting the CAPTION | TRAY flags.

member.summary: Flash the window caption.

member.summary: Stop flashing. The system restores the window to its original state.

member.summary: Flash continuously, until the STOP flag is set.

member.name: T:Native.MONITOR
member.summary: Flags for . Determines the function's return value if the window does not intersect any display monitor.

member.name: F:Native.MONITOR.DEFAULTTONULL
member.summary: Returns IntPtr.Zero.

member.name: F:Native.MONITOR.DEFAULTTOPRIMARY
member.summary: Returns a handle to the primary display monitor.

member.name: F:Native.MONITOR.DEFAULTTONEAREST
member.summary: Returns a handle to the display monitor that is nearest to the window.

member.name: F:Native.ULW.ALPHA
member.summary: Use pblend as the blend function. If the display mode is 256 colors or less, the effect of this value is the same as the effect of ULW_OPAQUE.

member.name: F:Native.ULW.COLORKEY
member.summary: Use crKey as the transparency color.

member.name: F:Native.ULW.ULW_OPAQUE
member.summary: Draw an opaque layered window.

member.name: T:Native.AW
member.summary: Flags for .

member.name: F:Native.AW.ACTIVATE
member.summary: Activates the window. Do not use this value with .

member.name: F:Native.AW.BLEND
member.summary: Uses a fade effect. This flag can be used only if hwnd is a top-level window.

member.name: F:Native.AW.CENTER
member.summary: Makes the window appear to collapse inward if is used or expand outward if the is not used. The various direction flags have no effect.

member.name: F:Native.AW.HIDE
member.summary: Hides the window. By default, the window is shown.

member.name: F:Native.AW.HOR_POSITIVE
member.summary: Animates the window from left to right. This flag can be used with roll or slide animation. It is ignored when used with or .

member.name: F:Native.AW.HOR_NEGATIVE
member.summary: Animates the window from right to left. This flag can be used with roll or slide animation. It is ignored when used with or .

member.name: F:Native.AW.SLIDE
member.summary: Uses slide animation. By default, roll animation is used. This flag is ignored when used with .

member.name: F:Native.AW.VER_POSITIVE
member.summary: Animates the window from top to bottom. This flag can be used with roll or slide animation. It is ignored when used with or .

member.name: F:Native.AW.VER_NEGATIVE
member.summary: Animates the window from bottom to top. This flag can be used with roll or slide animation. It is ignored when used with or .

member.name: T:Native.RDW
member.summary: Flags for .

member.name: F:Native.RDW.INVALIDATE
member.summary: Invalidates the rectangle or region that you specify in lprcUpdate or hrgnUpdate. You can set only one of these parameters to a non-NULL value. If both are NULL, RDW_INVALIDATE invalidates the entire window.

member.name: F:Native.RDW.INTERNALPAINT
member.summary: Causes the OS to post a WM_PAINT message to the window regardless of whether a portion of the window is invalid.

member.name: F:Native.RDW.ERASE
member.summary: Causes the window to receive a WM_ERASEBKGND message when the window is repainted. Specify this value in combination with the RDW_INVALIDATE value; otherwise, RDW_ERASE has no effect.

member.name: F:Native.RDW.VALIDATE
member.summary: Validates the rectangle or region that you specify in lprcUpdate or hrgnUpdate. You can set only one of these parameters to a non-NULL value. If both are NULL, RDW_VALIDATE validates the entire window. This value does not affect internal WM_PAINT messages.

member.name: F:Native.RDW.NOINTERNALPAINT
member.summary: Suppresses any pending internal WM_PAINT messages. This flag does not affect WM_PAINT messages resulting from a non-NULL update area.

member.name: F:Native.RDW.NOERASE
member.summary: Suppresses any pending WM_ERASEBKGND messages.

member.name: F:Native.RDW.NOCHILDREN
member.summary: Excludes child windows, if any, from the repainting operation.

member.name: F:Native.RDW.ALLCHILDREN
member.summary: Includes child windows, if any, in the repainting operation.

member.name: F:Native.RDW.UPDATENOW
member.summary: Causes the affected windows, which you specify by setting the RDW_ALLCHILDREN and RDW_NOCHILDREN values, to receive WM_ERASEBKGND and WM_PAINT messages before the RedrawWindow returns, if necessary.

member.name: F:Native.RDW.ERASENOW
member.summary: Causes the affected windows, which you specify by setting the RDW_ALLCHILDREN and RDW_NOCHILDREN values, to receive WM_ERASEBKGND messages before RedrawWindow returns, if necessary. The affected windows receive WM_PAINT messages at the ordinary time.

member.name: F:Native.RDW.FRAME
member.summary: Causes any part of the nonclient area of the window that intersects the update region to receive a WM_NCPAINT message. The RDW_INVALIDATE flag must also be specified; otherwise, RDW_FRAME has no effect. The WM_NCPAINT message is typically not sent during the execution of RedrawWindow unless either RDW_UPDATENOW or RDW_ERASENOW is specified.

member.name: F:Native.RDW.NOFRAME
member.summary: Suppresses any pending WM_NCPAINT messages. This flag must be used with RDW_VALIDATE and is typically used with RDW_NOCHILDREN. RDW_NOFRAME should be used with care, as it could cause parts of a window to be painted improperly.

member.name: F:Native.LoadLibraryFlags.DONT_RESOLVE_DLL_REFERENCES
member.summary: If this value is used, and the executable module is a DLL, the system does not call DllMain for process and thread initialization and termination. Also, the system does not load additional executable modules that are referenced by the specified module. Note Do not use this value; it is provided only for backward compatibility. If you are planning to access only data or resources in the DLL, use LOAD_LIBRARY_AS_DATAFILE_EXCLUSIVE or LOAD_LIBRARY_AS_IMAGE_RESOURCE or both. Otherwise, load the library as a DLL or executable module using the LoadLibrary function.

member.name: F:Native.LoadLibraryFlags.LOAD_IGNORE_CODE_AUTHZ_LEVEL
member.summary: If this value is used, the system does not check AppLocker rules or apply Software Restriction Policies for the DLL. This action applies only to the DLL being loaded and not to its dependencies. This value is recommended for use in setup programs that must run extracted DLLs during installation. Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7: On systems with KB2532445 installed, the caller must be running as "LocalSystem" or "TrustedInstaller"; otherwise the system ignores this flag.For more information, see "You can circumvent AppLocker rules by using an Office macro on a computer that is running Windows 7 or Windows Server 2008 R2" in the Help and Support Knowledge Base at http://support.microsoft.com/kb/2532445. Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista, Windows Server 2003, and Windows XP: AppLocker was introduced in Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2.

member.name: F:Native.LoadLibraryFlags.LOAD_LIBRARY_AS_DATAFILE
member.summary: If this value is used, the system maps the file into the calling process's virtual address space as if it were a data file. Nothing is done to execute or prepare to execute the mapped file. Therefore, you cannot call functions like GetModuleFileName, GetModuleHandle or GetProcAddress with this DLL. Using this value causes writes to read-only memory to raise an access violation. Use this flag when you want to load a DLL only to extract messages or resources from it. This value can be used with LOAD_LIBRARY_AS_IMAGE_RESOURCE.For more information, see Remarks.

member.name: F:Native.LoadLibraryFlags.LOAD_LIBRARY_AS_DATAFILE_EXCLUSIVE
member.summary: Similar to LOAD_LIBRARY_AS_DATAFILE, except that the DLL file is opened with exclusive write access for the calling process.Other processes cannot open the DLL file for write access while it is in use.However, the DLL can still be opened by other processes. This value can be used with LOAD_LIBRARY_AS_IMAGE_RESOURCE.For more information, see Remarks. Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: This value is not supported until Windows Vista.

member.name: F:Native.LoadLibraryFlags.LOAD_LIBRARY_AS_IMAGE_RESOURCE
member.summary: If this value is used, the system maps the file into the process's virtual address space as an image file. However, the loader does not load the static imports or perform the other usual initialization steps. Use this flag when you want to load a DLL only to extract messages or resources from it. Unless the application depends on the file having the in-memory layout of an image, this value should be used with either LOAD_LIBRARY_AS_DATAFILE_EXCLUSIVE or LOAD_LIBRARY_AS_DATAFILE.For more information, see the Remarks section. Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: This value is not supported until Windows Vista.

member.name: F:Native.LoadLibraryFlags.LOAD_LIBRARY_SEARCH_APPLICATION_DIR
member.summary: If this value is used, the application's installation directory is searched for the DLL and its dependencies. Directories in the standard search path are not searched. This value cannot be combined with LOAD_WITH_ALTERED_SEARCH_PATH. Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Vista, and Windows Server 2008: This value requires KB2533623 to be installed. Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:Native.LoadLibraryFlags.LOAD_LIBRARY_SEARCH_DEFAULT_DIRS
member.summary: This value is a combination of LOAD_LIBRARY_SEARCH_APPLICATION_DIR, LOAD_LIBRARY_SEARCH_SYSTEM32, and LOAD_LIBRARY_SEARCH_USER_DIRS. Directories in the standard search path are not searched.This value cannot be combined with LOAD_WITH_ALTERED_SEARCH_PATH. This value represents the recommended maximum number of directories an application should include in its DLL search path. Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Vista, and Windows Server 2008: This value requires KB2533623 to be installed. Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:Native.LoadLibraryFlags.LOAD_LIBRARY_SEARCH_DLL_LOAD_DIR
member.summary: If this value is used, the directory that contains the DLL is temporarily added to the beginning of the list of directories that are searched for the DLL's dependencies. Directories in the standard search path are not searched. The lpFileName parameter must specify a fully qualified path.This value cannot be combined with LOAD_WITH_ALTERED_SEARCH_PATH. For example, if Lib2.dll is a dependency of C:\Dir1\Lib1.dll, loading Lib1.dll with this value causes the system to search for Lib2.dll only in C:\Dir1.To search for Lib2.dll in C:\Dir1 and all of the directories in the DLL search path, combine this value with LOAD_LIBRARY_DEFAULT_DIRS. Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Vista, and Windows Server 2008: This value requires KB2533623 to be installed. Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:Native.LoadLibraryFlags.LOAD_LIBRARY_SEARCH_SYSTEM32
member.summary: If this value is used, %windows%\system32 is searched for the DLL and its dependencies.Directories in the standard search path are not searched.This value cannot be combined with LOAD_WITH_ALTERED_SEARCH_PATH. Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Vista, and Windows Server 2008: This value requires KB2533623 to be installed. Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:Native.LoadLibraryFlags.LOAD_LIBRARY_SEARCH_USER_DIRS
member.summary: If this value is used, directories added using the AddDllDirectory or the SetDllDirectory function are searched for the DLL and its dependencies.If more than one directory has been added, the order in which the directories are searched is unspecified.Directories in the standard search path are not searched.This value cannot be combined with LOAD_WITH_ALTERED_SEARCH_PATH. Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Vista, and Windows Server 2008: This value requires KB2533623 to be installed. Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:Native.LoadLibraryFlags.LOAD_WITH_ALTERED_SEARCH_PATH
member.summary: If this value is used and lpFileName specifies an absolute path, the system uses the alternate file search strategy discussed in the Remarks section to find associated executable modules that the specified module causes to be loaded. If this value is used and lpFileName specifies a relative path, the behavior is undefined. If this value is not used, or if lpFileName does not specify a path, the system uses the standard search strategy discussed in the Remarks section to find associated executable modules that the specified module causes to be loaded. This value cannot be combined with any LOAD_LIBRARY_SEARCH flag.

member.name: T:Native.SEM
member.summary: Flags for .

member.name: F:Native.SEM.Default
member.summary: Use the system default, which is to display all error dialog boxes.

member.name: F:Native.SEM.FAILCRITICALERRORS
member.summary: The system does not display the critical-error-handler message box. Instead, the system sends the error to the calling process.
member.remarks: Best practice is that all applications call the process-wide SetErrorMode function with a parameter of at startup. This is to prevent error mode dialogs from hanging the application.

member.name: F:Native.SEM.NOALIGNMENTFAULTEXCEPT
member.summary: The system automatically fixes memory alignment faults and makes them invisible to the application. It does this for the calling process and any descendant processes. This feature is only supported by certain processor architectures. After this value is set for a process, subsequent attempts to clear the value are ignored.

member.name: F:Native.SEM.NOGPFAULTERRORBOX
member.summary: The system does not display the Windows Error Reporting dialog.

member.name: F:Native.SEM.NOOPENFILEERRORBOX
member.summary: The system does not display a message box when it fails to find a file. Instead, the error is returned to the calling process.

member.name: T:Native.FILE_ATTRIBUTE
member.summary: File attribute flags.

member.name: F:Native.FILE_ATTRIBUTE.INVALID
member.summary: Error.

member.name: F:Native.FILE_ATTRIBUTE.ARCHIVE
member.summary: A file or directory that is an archive file or directory. Applications typically use this attribute to mark files for backup or removal.

member.name: F:Native.FILE_ATTRIBUTE.COMPRESSED
member.summary: A file or directory that is compressed. For a file, all of the data in the file is compressed. For a directory, compression is the default for newly created files and subdirectories.

member.name: F:Native.FILE_ATTRIBUTE.DEVICE
member.summary: This value is reserved for system use.

member.name: F:Native.FILE_ATTRIBUTE.DIRECTORY
member.summary: The handle that identifies a directory.

member.name: F:Native.FILE_ATTRIBUTE.ENCRYPTED
member.summary: A file or directory that is encrypted. For a file, all data streams in the file are encrypted. For a directory, encryption is the default for newly created files and subdirectories.

member.name: F:Native.FILE_ATTRIBUTE.HIDDEN
member.summary: The file or directory is hidden. It is not included in an ordinary directory listing.

member.name: F:Native.FILE_ATTRIBUTE.INTEGRITY_STREAM
member.summary: The directory or user data stream is configured with integrity (only supported on ReFS volumes). It is not included in an ordinary directory listing. The integrity setting persists with the file if it's renamed. If a file is copied the destination file will have integrity set if either the source file or destination directory have integrity set.
member.remarks: Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista, Windows Server 2003, and Windows XP: This flag is not supported until Windows Server 2012.

member.name: F:Native.FILE_ATTRIBUTE.NORMAL
member.summary: A file that does not have other attributes set. This attribute is valid only when used alone.

member.name: F:Native.FILE_ATTRIBUTE.NOT_CONTENT_INDEXED
member.summary: The file or directory is not to be indexed by the content indexing service.

member.name: F:Native.FILE_ATTRIBUTE.NO_SCRUB_DATA
member.summary: The user data stream not to be read by the background data integrity scanner (AKA scrubber). When set on a directory it only provides inheritance. This flag is only supported on Storage Spaces and ReFS volumes.It is not included in an ordinary directory listing.
member.remarks: Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista, Windows Server 2003, and Windows XP: This flag is not supported until Windows 8 and Windows Server 2012.

member.name: F:Native.FILE_ATTRIBUTE.OFFLINE
member.summary: The data of a file is not available immediately. This attribute indicates that the file data is physically moved to offline storage. This attribute is used by Remote Storage, which is the hierarchical storage management software. Applications should not arbitrarily change this attribute.

member.name: F:Native.FILE_ATTRIBUTE.READONLY
member.summary: A file that is read-only. Applications can read the file, but cannot write to it or delete it. This attribute is not honored on directories.

member.name: F:Native.FILE_ATTRIBUTE.REPARSE_POINT
member.summary: A file or directory that has an associated reparse point, or a file that is a symbolic link.

member.name: F:Native.FILE_ATTRIBUTE.SPARSE_FILE
member.summary: A file that is a sparse file.

member.name: F:Native.FILE_ATTRIBUTE.SYSTEM
member.summary: A file or directory that the operating system uses a part of, or uses exclusively.

member.name: F:Native.FILE_ATTRIBUTE.TEMPORARY
member.summary: A file that is being used for temporary storage. File systems avoid writing data back to mass storage if sufficient cache memory is available, because typically, an application deletes a temporary file after the handle is closed. In that scenario, the system can entirely avoid writing the data. Otherwise, the data is written after the handle is closed.

member.name: F:Native.FILE_ATTRIBUTE.VIRTUAL
member.summary: This value is reserved for system use.

member.name: T:Native.BITMAPINFOHEADER
member.summary: The BITMAPINFOHEADER structure contains information about the dimensions and color format of a DIB.

member.name: F:Native.BITMAPINFOHEADER.biSize
member.summary: The number of bytes required by the structure.

member.name: F:Native.BITMAPINFOHEADER.biWidth
member.summary: The width of the bitmap, in pixels.
member.remarks: If biCompression is BI_JPEG or BI_PNG, the biWidth member specifies the width of the decompressed JPEG or PNG image file, respectively.

member.name: F:Native.BITMAPINFOHEADER.biHeight
member.summary: The height of the bitmap, in pixels. If biHeight is positive, the bitmap is a bottom-up DIB and its origin is the lower-left corner. If biHeight is negative, the bitmap is a top-down DIB and its origin is the upper-left corner.
member.remarks: If biHeight is negative, indicating a top-down DIB, biCompression must be either BI_RGB or BI_BITFIELDS. Top-down DIBs cannot be compressed. If biCompression is BI_JPEG or BI_PNG, the biHeight member specifies the height of the decompressed JPEG or PNG image file, respectively.

member.name: F:Native.BITMAPINFOHEADER.biPlanes
member.summary: The number of planes for the target device. This value must be set to 1.

member.name: F:Native.BITMAPINFOHEADER.biBitCount
member.summary: The number of bits-per-pixel. The biBitCount member of the BITMAPINFOHEADER structure determines the number of bits that define each pixel and the maximum number of colors in the bitmap. This member must be one of the following values: 0, 1, 4, 8, 16, 24, 32

member.name: F:Native.BITMAPINFOHEADER.biCompression
member.summary: The type of compression for a compressed bottom-up bitmap (top-down DIBs cannot be compressed).

member.name: F:Native.BITMAPINFOHEADER.biSizeImage
member.summary: The size, in bytes, of the image. This may be set to zero for BI_RGB bitmaps.

member.name: F:Native.BITMAPINFOHEADER.biXPelsPerMeter
member.summary: The horizontal resolution, in pixels-per-meter, of the target device for the bitmap. An application can use this value to select a bitmap from a resource group that best matches the characteristics of the current device.

member.name: F:Native.BITMAPINFOHEADER.biYPelsPerMeter
member.summary: The vertical resolution, in pixels-per-meter, of the target device for the bitmap.

member.name: F:Native.BITMAPINFOHEADER.biClrUsed
member.summary: The number of color indexes in the color table that are actually used by the bitmap. If this value is zero, the bitmap uses the maximum number of colors corresponding to the value of the biBitCount member for the compression mode specified by biCompression.

member.name: F:Native.BITMAPINFOHEADER.biClrImportant
member.summary: The number of color indexes that are required for displaying the bitmap. If this value is zero, all colors are required.

member.summary: Contains information about the size and position of a window.

member.name: F:Native.WINDOWPOS.hwnd
member.summary: A handle to the window.

member.name: F:Native.WINDOWPOS.hwndInsertAfter
member.summary: The position of the window in Z order (front-to-back position). This member can be a handle to the window behind which this window is placed, or can be one of the special values listed with the SetWindowPos function.

member.name: F:Native.WINDOWPOS.x
member.summary: The position of the left edge of the window.

member.name: F:Native.WINDOWPOS.y
member.summary: The position of the top edge of the window.

member.name: F:Native.WINDOWPOS.cx
member.summary: The window width, in pixels.

member.name: F:Native.WINDOWPOS.cy
member.summary: The window height, in pixels.

member.name: F:Native.WINDOWPOS.flags
member.summary: The window position. This member can be one or more of the following values:

member.name: T:Native.DWM_BLURBEHIND
member.summary: Specifies Desktop Window Manager (DWM) blur-behind properties. Used by the function.

member.name: F:Native.DWM_BLURBEHIND.dwFlags
member.summary: A bitwise combination of constant values that indicates which of the members of this structure have been set.

member.name: F:Native.DWM_BLURBEHIND.fEnable
member.summary: true to register the window handle to DWM blur behind; false to unregister the window handle from DWM blur behind.

member.name: F:Native.DWM_BLURBEHIND.hRgnBlur
member.summary: The region within the client area where the blur behind will be applied. A IntPtr.Zero value will apply the blur behind the entire client area.

member.name: F:Native.DWM_BLURBEHIND.fTransitionOnMaximized
member.summary: true if the window's colorization should transition to match the maximized windows; otherwise, false.

member.name: T:Native.FLASHWINFO
member.summary: Contains the flash status for a window and the number of times the system should flash the window.

member.name: F:Native.FLASHWINFO.cbSize
member.summary: The size of the structure, in bytes.

member.name: F:Native.FLASHWINFO.hwnd
member.summary: A handle to the window to be flashed. The window can be either opened or minimized.

member.name: F:Native.FLASHWINFO.dwFlags
member.summary: The flash status.

member.name: F:Native.FLASHWINFO.uCount
member.summary: The number of times to flash the window.

member.name: F:Native.FLASHWINFO.dwTimeout
member.summary: The rate at which the window is to be flashed, in milliseconds. If dwTimeout is zero, the function uses the default cursor blink rate.

member.name: T:Native.MINMAXINFO
member.summary: Contains information about a window's maximized size and position and its minimum and maximum tracking size.
member.remarks: For systems with multiple monitors, the ptMaxSize and ptMaxPosition members describe the maximized size and position of the window on the primary monitor, even if the window ultimately maximizes onto a secondary monitor. In that case, the window manager adjusts these values to compensate for differences between the primary monitor and the monitor that displays the window. Thus, if the user leaves ptMaxSize untouched, a window on a monitor larger than the primary monitor maximizes to the size of the larger monitor.

member.name: F:Native.MINMAXINFO.ptReserved
member.summary: Reserved; do not use.

member.name: F:Native.MINMAXINFO.ptMaxSize
member.summary: The maximized width (x member) and the maximized height (y member) of the window. For top-level windows, this value is based on the width of the primary monitor.

member.name: F:Native.MINMAXINFO.ptMaxPosition
member.summary: The position of the left side of the maximized window (x member) and the position of the top of the maximized window (y member). For top-level windows, this value is based on the position of the primary monitor.

member.name: F:Native.MINMAXINFO.ptMinTrackSize
member.summary: The minimum tracking width (x member) and the minimum tracking height (y member) of the window. This value can be obtained programmatically from the system metrics SM_CXMINTRACK and SM_CYMINTRACK (see the GetSystemMetrics function).

member.name: F:Native.MINMAXINFO.ptMaxTrackSize
member.summary: The maximum tracking width (x member) and the maximum tracking height (y member) of the window. This value is based on the size of the virtual screen and can be obtained programmatically from the system metrics SM_CXMAXTRACK and SM_CYMAXTRACK (see the GetSystemMetrics function).

member.name: T:Native.MONITORINFO
member.summary: Contains information about a display monitor.

member.name: F:Native.MONITORINFO.cbSize
member.summary: The size of the structure, in bytes.

member.name: F:Native.MONITORINFO.rcMonitor
member.summary: A structure that specifies the display monitor rectangle, expressed in virtual-screen coordinates. Note that if the monitor is not the primary display monitor, some of the rectangle's coordinates may be negative values.

member.name: F:Native.MONITORINFO.rcWork
member.summary: A structure that specifies the work area rectangle of the display monitor, expressed in virtual-screen coordinates. Note that if the monitor is not the primary display monitor, some of the rectangle's coordinates may be negative values.

member.name: F:Native.MONITORINFO.dwFlags
member.summary: A set of flags that represent attributes of the display monitor.

member.name: T:Native.WIN32_STREAM_ID
member.summary: Contains stream data.

member.name: F:Native.WIN32_STREAM_ID.dwStreamId
member.summary: Type of data.

member.name: F:Native.WIN32_STREAM_ID.dwStreamAttributes
member.summary: Attributes of data to facilitate cross-operating system transfer.

member.name: F:Native.WIN32_STREAM_ID.Size
member.summary: Size of data, in bytes.

member.name: F:Native.WIN32_STREAM_ID.dwStreamNameSize
member.summary: Length of the name of the alternative data stream, in bytes.
